body.p: It is within the last quarter of an hour that I have read the unwelcome and painful news of the death of your son. I came in from Stockport on sunday and found the paper here ; but, on asking, T.P.C. had seen nothing it it. I had company and had to return to Stockport, so I put it by for another day's perusal. It occurred to me this morning, the first here for a week, that you had sent the paper for something in it ; I saw Otley's poetry and the Anticorporation meeting but never dreamt of a death concerning me. I began to look at the marriages, to see if Mary Ann had got married, and then my eye glanced on this unhappy death. I really grieve with you for the loss of this boy because I had formed high hopes of him: he was one of the [[2]] best youths I had met in the country and I have often wished that my boys were like him. I suppose the winter was too severe for him. It has, in Manchester, tried me much since Christmas, caused me to neglect my room, which too has been intolerably cold, so that I have not had a good audience since Christmas. I am beginning to move again for the present year. iIt is well I have found a purse ; for I find it difficult to get any income from preaching. Three wednesday evenings, I have been sparring with Beard about Trinity and Unity; but he is very shy of me. I am in hope to bring out some of them for discussion: at least, this is what I aim at. Mrs. C. is at Enfield but will join me soon. I spent three weeks with her at Christmas. I hope to make this a fruitful year. I have felt for some days that it was time I wrote you a letter. I sent you a settling parcel just before I left Manchester for London which I hope you have safely received.

[[3]] Express my sympathy and condolence with Mrs Turton, Mary Ann and Jane. I cannot imagine any thing that could have been an equal loss to you. Excepting Alfred, neither of my boys promises to be anything; while I had pictured yours as one of my future preachers.
I shall be glad to have a letter from you after a few weeks that you have passed the acuteness of your loss.

It is of no use to talk to you of the will of Divine Providence. My God the father is the Law of Necessity and the loss of this fine boy is a proof of it. God the Son could not save his physical life though it had endowed him with intellectual life. I had not entertained the idea that his illness would lead to premature death â€” Grieve moderately. I must allow a little for I should and do grieve for him myself.
